titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1846. Thursday 4. June— At the Pension Office— Letter from Asa Gray— Tiverton R.I
American Archives 4th. Series Vol. 6. p 703
Call at Gadsby’s— Mr and Mrs. Abbott Lawrence

Kilty— Nathan Appleton— H.R.U.S.— Army Bill. 1. additional major General 2. Brigadier Generals— Soldiers pay: 10 dollars a month and 160 acres of Land— Invitation from R. C. Winthrop to party this Evening— Strawberries— Eve at home
Heat oppressive— Thom— Matamoros taken

Friday 5. June— Edward Everett— Addresses at his inauguration as President of Harvard University 30. April 1846.— Daguerrotype likeness of my sister— H.R.U.S. Private Calendar Committee of the whole— Oppressive heat— Excessive depression— Evening visit from Asa Whitney. His projected railway to Columbia river. Says a bill will be reported to S.U.S— China— Isthmus of Panama— Japan— Australia— New-Zealand. Madagascar—

Saturday. 6. June V— My Son, with his Son C. F arrived. Kevasales here— H.R.U.S. Bills from Comee of the whole one the private Calendar Failing Quorum— Motion to suspend the Rules for a resolution to meet hereafter at 10. A.M. not 2/3 Voted to meet at 10 Monday next— Resolution to adjourn 20 July not carried but will be. Adjourned about 2
Half walk home— Met Fuller and the carriage opposite Coleman’s— After dinner— Walk round the Octagon— John Pope here— Going to Matamoros

Received from Pension Office, two Pension certificates for Sarah B. Lake and Hannah Manchester children of Susanna Borden deceased widow of Josiah Borden a Seaman of the Revolution. of Tiverton Rhode-Island.

Sunday 7 June 1846— Hall HRUS. Stranger prayed— Tustin preached— Acts 26.28. P.M. St. John’s Church Mr Pyne 1. John 5.7. Trinity Sunday— Healy and Hart evening visitors— Hart a sculptor from Kentucky— Statue of Henry Clay—
Monday 8. June 1846.— Answered the Letter of Asa Gray of Tiverton R. Island— Keep the pension certificates of Sarah B. Lake and Hannah Manchester. Charles and his son went with me to H.R.U.S.
Tuesday 9. June 1846.— Company to dine. Theodore L. Moody and Isaac Hull Adams here in the Evening—

Wednesday 10. June 1846. My Son, and his Son Charles left us to return to Boston— H.R.U.S. Timothy Pilsbury, second member from Texas. Motion to reconsider the vote to reinstate J. T. Stewart as Messenger laid on the table— Wisconsin Constitution
Bill debated and passed— Bill for regulating and distributing Clerk’s offices in Washington— Memorial from New-York Ladies in favour of the Old Army Officers— Message P.U.S. to S.U.S. Oregon Settlements
Healy here and Hart sculptor from Kentucky.

H.R.U.S— W. Sawyer’s personal explanation, and discussion with A. Stewart— Office rotation bill— Army Paymasters— Navy Appropriation bill— Nautical Almanac. 5000.— Navy Yard Brooklyn— Wall under frigate Sabine— Dry—floating and sectional Stone Dock— Philadelphia, Pensacola— Kittery— Indian appropriation bill— Expenses of rotation and militia

Letter from H. E. Insley, with Daguerrotype of my Sister’s portrait, answered. Senate— Oregon Settlement. HRU.S.— Haralson’s personal explanation in defence of the military Comee. T. B. King from Naval Comee. reports a Bill to contract for Ocean Mail-Steamers.— Message from S.U.S— Amendments to Bill of Declaration of War against Mexico— Schenk reports from the Select Committee on C. J. Ingersoll’s breach of the Seal of Confidence, of secret Archives in the Department of State— Facts and Testimony
but no conclusion— Laid on the table and ordered to be printed and communicated to P.U.S. and Secretary of State— Report by Samuel Gordon chairman of a select Committee on the purchase and printing of a tenth volume of U.S. Laws—morning hour expired— House refuse to go into Committee of the whole on the bill to reduce and graduate the price of public Lands— Washington Hunt moved to suspend the rules for a Resolution to present medals to Genl Taylor and his Officers—rejected— Cobb moved to suspend the rules for a motion to make the daily hour of meeting 10. AM— Carried. Collamer moved to add 3. pm for the hour of adjournment— Lost— Brinkerhoff moved a Resolution to pay the soldiers 10 dollars a month, lost— Message from P.U.S—with Genl Taylors detailed Reports of the battles of Palo Alto 8 and of Resaca de la Palma 9. May— Woodworth moved a call on Secretary of War for reports on the Lake Superior Mineral Lands. Carried— Sundry private bills taken up and passed— Adjourned— Healy and Hart here.
Letter from Otis Drury, 10 June—had not received his money— Must have received it ere this— Letter from Mrs Maria Weston Chapman Invitation to Dedham 4. July, close at hand.

H.R.U.S— Debate on purchase and distribution of the 10th volume of U.S. Laws postponed. Navy Appropriation bill in Comee. of the whole on the State of the Union.— Levin, dry dock at Philadelphia— Hardin, at Kittery. I. E. Holmes at Charleston— T. B. King at Savannah— Stanton Navy-Yard at Memphis— Appropriations for the Marine Corps— Henderson Brevet Brigadier General— R.C. Winthrop— Brockenbrough and Pensacola— Numerous amendments rejected— Bill reported to the house. I. E. Holmes moves previous question— Adjourned

H.R.U.S. Mr Anderson of Salem Orthodox Hebrews 12.2. No singing— Mr and Mrs. C. P Cranch dined with us— 2d. Presbyterian Church. Craighead— St. John’s 1st. Sunday after Trinity 1. Corinthians 7.31.— Mr and Mrs Cranch went to A. Campbell’s—

Monday 15. June 1846.— Mr Charles Philips with Letter from D. M. Barringer and a copy of my father’s thoughts on Government.— I answered the Letter of W. W. Story Son of the late judge Joseph Story— Boston— H.R.U.S. Lewis C. Levin complained of an attack upon him in the Union Newspaper by John S. Gilbert
charging him with offering to speculate with him in sectional floating dry and stone docks Navy Appropriation bill—5000 dollars for American Nautical almanac struck out— Philadelphia Dry-dock struck out— Memphis Rope walk. Bill passed 191 to 2. Appropriation 7.741822—

Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Cobb in the Chair— M’Kay calls up the Tariff bill— Message from SU.S. conference on the supplementary declaration of War Bill— Haralson Boyd and White.— Culver’s speech against the Mexican War— Hungerford moves a substitute for the Tariff Bill— Debate on the Indian Appropriation bill to close at 2. P.M. to-morrow.

Williams, a Swede from Cincinnati— I went with Levi Lovering to the Pension Office, He has two pension claims, one for Elizabeth M’Farland widow of Walter M’Farland and one for himself and his sister children of Jesse Lovering. Left him with his documents at the Pension Office— Plumbe’s Gallery— Daguerrotype taken for Williams the Swede from Cincinnati— Letters to Asa Gray, enclosing two pension certificates for Sarah B. Lake and Hannah Manchester— HR.U.S. Joseph J. M’Dowell of Ohio moved
a suspension of the rules to offer three Resolutions against the Treaty for the settlement of the Oregon bounary now before the Senate— Suspension of the rules refused 27 to 115— G. W. Hopkins asked leave to give notice of a resolution that no motion should during the remainder of this session be entertained for a suspension of the rules, unless seconded by a majority of the members present— Not received. Committee of the whole on the State of the Union Howell Cobb in the Chair— Indian appropriation bill— T. Pilsbury from Texas—hour speech. Alexander Stephens of Georgia, hour speech against the War.— Shelton F. Leake of Virginia hour speech in reply.— William L. Yancey of Alabama, and John A. M’Clernand of Illinois same and same— Committee rose— Haralson from the Committee of Conference on the supplementary war bill against Mexico repeated that the house should recede from the amendments to which the Senate had signed. Report after some debate accepted 94 to 54— Senate’s amendments to the Indian appropriation bill resumed and further debated till the adjournment— I gave D. M. Barringer a Memorial from the Historical Society of the University of North Carolina to Congress which Mr Charles Phillips had left with me.

Answered the Letter of Mrs. Maria Weston Chapman inviting me to a meeting at Dedham on the 4th. of July—declined— Sent Levi Lovering 10 dollars to pay his expenses in going home. Anniversary of Bunker hill battle— Daniel P King made two attempts to call up the bill for erecting a monument to General Joseph Warren—both failed.— The Select Committee on the purchase of the 10th. volume of U.S. Laws reported by Samuel Gordon, a Resolution for distribution to the Members of Congress, as the 8th and 9th volumes were distributed— Indian Appropriation bill. Amendments of the Senate disposed— Previous Question— those . . . moved, and at last carried— Post-Office Appropriation bill— Senate Amendments all concurred in—8500 dollars appropriated for printing a new edition 18000 copies of the table of Post Offices and Laws and regulations of the Post-Office— Bill passed— Reports called from all the Committees— Hamlin from the Committee of Elections reported a Resolution to pay C J. Ingersoll for a contested election of the 26th Congress, up to 15 Jany 1848—and John Taliaferro for 1. Session of 13th. Congress to 2. August 1813, and 2d. Session of 13 Congress to 17. Feby 1814— Laid on the table 113 to 39— Seaborn Jones from the Select Committee on C. J. Ingersoll’s charges against Daniel Webster offered a Resolution to print all the sealed up testimony— Carried after a struggle— W. W. Campbell from select Committee reported a bill to move the Consular system of U.S. read and committed— Report on lake Superior
Mineral Lands— Message from P.U.S. With Reports from the Secretary of the Navy, and correspondence between Commodore G. J Pendergrast, and the Government on the Rio de la Plata, and the foreign naval commanders and the United States Minister at Buenos Ayres and the Navy Department— Evening within the President’s house grounds— Revd M. Hale Smith— Robert Greenhow— Oregon Treaty ratified 41 to 14—

Received a Letter from John D. Munford H.R.U.S. Reading of half the journal dispensed with, Bitter personal altercation between Stephens of Georgia and Yancey of Alabama— Comee of the whole on the state of the Union— Tariff Bill— Elias B. Holmes 28th Congressional District of New-York speech against the Mexican War Abraham R. M’Ilvaine 7th. Congressional district of Pennsylvania Speech against the Tariff-bill.— Speech first of Seaborn Jones of Georgia instead of MKay.— Bryan R. Young of Kentucky took the floor— Comee rose after taking up navy pension bill— M’Kay moves to strike out 3000 dollars for privateer . . . Debate— D. P. King— Isaac E. Holmes, support the appropriation— No quorum— Adjourn 1/2 past 3. Evening walk round Octagon square.

I received a Letter from Benjamin Matthias and 6. others a Committee of the whig Citizens of Philadelphia—inviting me to a public dinner on the 4th. of July.— H.R.U.S. Brinkerhoff moved to suspend the rules for a motion to print all the testimony in the Webster investigation case—refused 60 to 77.— M’Kay moved a resolution to close debate on the tariff bill— Tuesday the 30th. laid on the table— Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— Cobb—Chairman—on the Tariff Bill— Speech of Brian R Young against the Bill and for protection— Robert Dale Owen— John F. Collin of New-York, read, and John S. Chipman of Michigan, per contra Alexander Ramsey for protection and the coal trade, Bill laid aside—pre-emption land bill from the Senate and two others reported to the house—and adjourned—

The Senate yesterday advised and consented to the ratification of the Oregon partition Treaty— Mr William A. Pratt Daguerrean Artist this day took a type of me in the Committee room of the Committee of Post Offices and Post roads of the House— At the third trial he succeeded tolerably well— The first and second trials were failures.— I received also a Letter of political casuistical enquires—from Jesse Torrey junr. of Montezuma, Cayuga County New-York— 16. June 1846.

I enclosed this day, an order from the Bank of the Metropolis on the Merchants Bank Baltimore for 30 dollars, in my favour, endorsed payable to James Cortlan and Son, in payment for the refrigerator, ordered by Mrs Adams, and received— H.RU.S— Robert M’Clelland of Michigan, presented proceedings of a Meeting at Detroit and George W Jones Resolutions of the Legislature of Tennessee— Samuel Gordon called up his Reconsideration of the vote rejecting the distribution of the 10th volume of the Laws reported by him as chairman of the select Comee. No Quorum Seaman moves a call of the House—refused 31 to 96— Straggling debate— Rejected distribution reconsidered 99 to 45—and distribution resolution adopted 100 to 59— Private bills superseded— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Cobb Chairman— Tariff bill, Speeches of Darragh and Sawyer on the Mexican War, the boundary of Texas, and the Oregon boundary treaty— Sawyer’s ludicrous lamentations. discussion between Andrew Johnson, George W. Jones and Seaborn Jones whether Tea and Coffee are necessaries of life or mere comforts and suitable for taxation— Collamer moved to lay the bill aside, rejected but the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Evening visits from Mrs Madison and Madison and Mary E. E. Cutts Richard P. Herrick member fromCongressional district of New-York died.

My wife and Mrs John Adams are both very ill, confined to their beds; and though not myself confined even to the house, Patience and Resignation are my duties— At the Hall of the House of Representatives I heard Mr Milburn from 2. Kings 20.1.— [“]Thus saith the Lord: set thine house in order; for thou shalt die and not live”— Richard P. Herrick member of the house from the 12th. Congressional district of New-York died last night— I walked from the Capitol home— After dinner at the second Presbyterian Church Revd. Joshua Danforth preached from 1. Thessalonians 5.17 Pray without ceasing— Argumentative discourse upon prayer— Walter Hellen went to his mother who is very sick— Sudden change of weather from heat to cold last evening.— Dr Thomas here.— No Service at St. John’s Church this afternoon— Mr Pyne being sick.

H.R.U.S. Charles H. Carroll 29 Congressional District of New-York announced the decease of his colleague; pronounced according to custom his eulogy, and moved the usual resolutions of condolement with his family—to attend his funeral at noon to morrow—to wear crape 30 days—to notify the Senate and invite them to attend the funeral, and to adjourn to 12 to-morrow. Carried unanimously— I walked home.

Father Green (George) here with papers of two pension claims—and incessant bavardage. I took them to the Pension Office. Mr Edwards promised to report upon them— Revd. Joshua Danforth here mendicant for his church—second presbyterian church Alexandria—gave him 5. dollars. Evening walk round behind Franklin row. My wife and Mary ill in bed— I sleep in the Northern upper chamber— W. Hellen gone. Dr Thomas—pills and potions.

Father Green again— More pension claims Bradford Lincoln of Hingham, brought me a Letter from Thomas Loring— I promised to introduce him at1/2 past 12 this morning at the Congress Library—did so—and he took out a book charged to me— At Noon funeral of Richard P. Herrick— Prayer by Mr Milburn. Discourse by Mr Tustin— P.U.S. and Cabinet there except J. Y. Mason— Rode to and from the cemetery with Collamer Dixon and John A Rockwell— Before I reached the Hall of the House the Speaker had returned resumed the chair and adjourned the house till to morrow at 10 I walked from the Capitol home— Mr Grinnell returned from a visit to New Bedford— Saw Sidney Brooks in Boston— Family well— Twilight walk overtaken by a shower near the West end of the
Navy Department where I took refuge— Mrs M’Kean, sent me by a coloured boy an Umbrella— Short Shower— Dr Thomas— My wife and Mary confined to their beds— Cold rain— Snow at New-York—
Saint John Baptist. Ghent 1814.

lg.l: O! grand Saint Jean c’etait alors ta fete—

div.p:
Father Green a daily visitor. Pension claim papers of Eunice, widow of John Shepherd— I took them to the pension Office and left them with Mr Edwards, who returned and reported on them this Evening— Received Letter and rect. from James Cortlan and Son Baltimore— Also slip from Eaton Michigan Eagle Newspaper containing notices of John S. Chipman, a member of the house from that State H.R.U.S— M’Kay moved a resolution to close debate on the Tariff bill on Thursday 2 July, at 2 P.M.— Call of the House—146 answer M’Kay’s resolution carried 101. to 69.— C. J. Ingersoll from the Committee of foreign Affairs presented two reports, one of Reasons for the war with Mexico. Though the War Message was not referred to that Committee— The other a repetition of the Amistad Report and bill— Ordered to be reprinted Comee of the whole on the state of the Union Cobb Chairman— Tariff bill— Collamer made an hour speech for the protective system. Harmonson 3d. Congressional district of Louisiana an insolent and abusive anti-tariff speech— Asa Biggs of 9th Congressional District of North Carolina another— Washington Hunt . . .
pleasant tariff speech— Winthrop took the floor. Committee rose 46 to 32. no quorum Call of the house moved and lost— Motion to adjourn lost 39 to 56— Call moved again and lost— Adjourn 43 to 42 Evening walk round garden square. My wife and Mary yet sick in bed— Dr Thomas here— I sleep in the upper chamber— Belated for the music.— D. Webster war and revenue speech in the Senate—

I have received from Mrs Macomb widow of the late Major General Macomb, a kind Letter with a Georgetown Advocate Newspaper containing an Article by her brother RevdBalch—a narrative of the wedding party ofWard, at Commodore Thomas ap Catesby Jones’s in 1842 and his conversation with me then and there, much embroidered— Also a Letter from the Commissioner of Pensions Edwards returning with harsh comment Father Green’s papers of Sarah Clark. At the House—Committee of the whole on the state of the Union Cobb chairman— Tariff Bill— Robert C. Winthrop made an excellent tariff hour speech Edmund W. Hubard. 4th. Congressional district Anti-tariff. John H. Ewing 20th. Congressional district of Pennsylvania whig, Richard Brodhead of the 10th and John Strohm of the 8th. democrats all against the bill and for protection. Lucien B. Chase, 9th. C.D. of Tennessee moved Committee to rise— No! 7 to 76. No Quorum—must rise. Call of the House 93 answered— Motions to suspend the call and to adjourn lost—absentees called 27 excused—further proceedings superseded—adjourned— Evening walk— Met P.U.S. alone.

Morning visit from Revd. Daniel Baker, heretofore Minister of 2d. Presbyterian church here now of Holly Springs Mississippi— he now brought me five copies of his volume of revival Sermons for which I had subscribed— He earnestly intreated me to read the 3d. Christ the mediator— H.R.U.S. Ashmun moved a suspension of the Rules for a Resolution directing the Secretary of War to settle and adjust by adjust by arbitration the dispute between U.S. and David Ames of Springfield about water power in Mill river—refused— Bill from the Senate to organize a volunteer force and for the appointment of officers— Haralson moved to pass the bill without reference to Committee of the whole—but the bill gives the appointment of the Officers to P.U.S— Amendments were moved for the appointment of them according to the State Laws or by the volunteers themselves. Previous question twice moved and failed The third time it succeeded and the bill passed as it came from the Senate.— Comee of the whole on the state of the Union— Cobb Chairman— Tariff bill— Winthrop closed his speech yesterday with 5 propositions against repeal of the tariff—and for an issue of 8 or 10 Millions— Treasury Notes— John H. Ewing, 20th and John Strohm 8 Congressional district of Pennsylvania made Tariff speeches yesterday— This day Lucien B Chase of Tennessee, and Samuel Gordon 10
New-York discoursed Anti-tariff, and John A. Rockwell 3. Connecticut Tariff.— Bedinger 10. Virginia took the floor— Comee rose— Adjourned

Received a tart Letter from J. L. Edwards Commissioner of Pensions, returning for father Green the pension claim papers of Sarah Clark and Catharine O’Neal— Also a Letter from Dudley C. Evans of Worcester with enquiries concerning the Statistics of Slavery— H.R.U.S. M’Kay moved that the Clerk of the house B. B. French have leave of absence next week not to exceed 4 days—granted— Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Tariff Bill— Bedinger for the Bill— Ewing of Tennessee against it— Towns of Georgia and Severance of Maine spoke for and against the Bill— Tibbatts took the floor—no Quorum— Motion to take a recess and for a call of the house failed— Adjourn to Monday, Isaac Hull Adams here this Evening— Had a Letter from his Sister Elizabeth Yesterday, from Quincy.

At the Hall— H.R.U.S. Mr Tustin preached from John 5.40. empty benches.— Afternoon at 2d. presbyterian church Revd. Charles H. Nourse preached from Luke 12.8.9. Rain all the Evening— My wife and Mary still confined to their beds.

I have received two Letters from George Bartol junr at Boston, soliciting my advice to obtain the release from prison of Captain P. Flowry convicted of Slave trading— H.R.U.S. James Thompson moves for a daily recess of 2 hours during the debate on the Tariff bill— George S. Houston of Alabama moves as a substitute that it shall not be in order to move the Committee to rise before 7. P.M— Carried, and the house sat till 7. P.M. Tibbatts, of Kentucky Payne of Alabama and James A Seddon 6 Virginia made speeches for the bill— Hudson for the Tariff of 1842. Charles Goodyear 21 New York for Hungerford’s substituteKaufman of Texas in honour of the war against Mexico— Between 4 and 5 I came home, dined, and returned to the house, found John Blanchard 17 Pennsylvania speaking for protection and the tariff of 1842— Hungerford 19 New-York read a speech in support of his own bill, and against that reported by the Committee of Ways and Means. Henry J. Seaman 2. New-York spoke against the Bill— James Dixon 1. Connecticut took the floor at 7. P.M. Committee rose— Adjourned

I received yesterday a few lines from my Son covering a memorial from the Massachusetts Historical Society to Congress and I breathe freely again— This day I answered the invitation of Benjamin Matthias and a Committee of whigs of Philadelphia to a public dinner
there, on the anniversary 4. July declined. H.R.U.S— James Dixon 1. Connecticut. Tariff hour Speech—very good— Jacob Brinkerhoff, 11. Ohio Plain talk— Tells what Ohio will do, and what she will not do— What he will and what he will not do—he will not do—he will not vote for this bill? I whispered to my neighbour Hugh White—he will Thomas H. Bayly 7. Virginia— Anti-protection— John H. M’Henry 2. Kentucky. Protection— William L. Yancey 3. Alabama—read Pennsylvania out of the ranks of Democracy— Bannon G. Thibodaux 2. Louisiana protection for sugar. I took C. Hughes to Coleman’s— R. C. Winthrop invited me to dine at his lodgings— I engaged for to morrow— I came home, dined and returned.— George P. Marsh had made while I was absent a beautiful protection speech—but I heard part of an anti-tariff speech read by Charles S. Benton 17. New-York— Henry S Clarke 8. North-Carolina took the same— Timothy Jenkins 20 New-York, the other side— James Thompson 23. Pennsylvania Erie District replied to Yancey’s excommunication and at 7. P.M the house adjourned— I came home in torrents of rain which continued all night—
